page.title: 06Local History- Lochgelly
page.content:
The name Lochgelly is of Gaelic origin, either the bright lake or loch of the leeches. In the early 19th Century this was a weaving village but after the discovery of large deposits of coal, Lochgelly at one time was one of the most important mining towns in Scotland. Lochgelly lies 182 metres above sea level, which makes it the highest town in Fife. The main shops are located in Bank St. and Main St. but for a greater variety people will travel to Kirkcaldy, 18km S.E. and Dunfermline, 13 km S.W. Edinburgh 32km S can be reached by road and rail.
A focal point in the town is Lochgelly Centre which hosts a wide variety of activities.
